Award.AwardTitle: IGERT: Nanostructured Materials for Energy Storage and Conversion

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Integrative Graduate Education and Research Traineeship (IGERT) award supports the further development of a multidisciplinary graduate training program of education and research in Nanostructured Materials for Energy Storage and Conversion at the Georgia Institute of Technology. Intellectual Merit: The purpose of this program is to provide doctoral students with enhanced multidisciplinary training in the skills required for conducting research in energy science, technology and policy. This IGERT training aims to address all the stages of needed technological developments, starting from materials, to the fabrication of devices, to the integration of devices into systems, and how energy policy and economics may impact each of these stages, thus affecting the advancement and adoption of new energy solutions.

Broader Impacts: The program will advance knowledge of the economics of energy choices and policy development with sophisticated technical awareness of alternative technologies. Professors and students from neighboring HBCUs will be involved in the IGERT?s research and educational activities. A required component of the program is a set of four courses; first is an introductory seminar course, followed by a set of courses designed to provide participants with cross-disciplinary training in policy and technology. Next will be a set of studio courses designed to investigate and solve problems in the area of energy and energy policy by teams of students. International collaborations, industrial and national laboratory internships, and personal development seminars will help to create ethical, responsible and capable leaders of the future.

IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to catalyze a cultural change in graduate education by establishing innovative new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As part of the Nanomaterials for Energy Storage and Conversion IGERT program, graduate students in science and engineering departments engaged with students in policy, history and economics departments to explore how these different elements impact each other.  The research and coursework associated with the IGERT brought together students from varying disciplines and encouraged them to work on projects that differed from their individual Ph.D. research.  Trainees worked in multidisciplinary teams composed of policy experts, mechanical engineers, materials scientists, chemical engineers, chemists, and science and technology historians to study energy and research policy, and emerging materials and technologies. As an integral part of their coursework, they conducted outreach to stakeholders in the energy regulatory community, particularly those in the Southeastern electric power regulatory community. They also assessed needs for new modeling abilities and ways in which useful models could be built for policy practitioners in the Southeast region. They became comfortable extending their more narrowly-focused hands-on scientific research experience to broader studies of state-of-the-art technologies impacting energy usage both in the US and globally -- including grid energy storage systems, LED lighting, photovoltaics, and wide-bandgap power electronics. They became equally familiar with opportunities presented by and market barriers to energy efficiency investments, how to calculate levelized cost of energy for a given energy technology, and possible global political ramifications if the US were to export significant quantities of natural gas.
